text:
Q: Add two numbers in python? A:

You have used 12 in place of l2 and --> in place of ->


class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, val=0, next=None):
        self.val = val
        self.next = next
class Solution:

    def addTwoNumbers(self, l1:ListNode, l2: ListNode)  --> ListNode:
       dummy = ListNode(0)

       current = dummy 
       carry = 0

       while l1 or l2 or carry:

        val1 = l1.val if l1 else 0 
        val2 = l2.val if 12 else 0

        total = val1 + val2 + carry
        carry = total // 10
        digit = total % 10

        current.next = ListNode(digit)
        current = current.next

        l1 = l1.next if l1 else None
        l2 = l2.next if l2 else None

  return dummy.next

Q: Is it possible to create one interface for testbench and for modules connection? A:

Is it possible to create one interface for testbench and for modules connection?

Yes, it is possible to create an interface that can be used in both design and testbench modules. This is a common practice.

Am I misunderstanding the purpose of interfaces?

In this case, yes, there is some misunderstanding of usage.

Is it possible to get rid of this warnings?

It behaves as expected aside from the warnings.

It is great that you are paying attention to the warnings and that you are also trying to fix them. That shows great instincts.

commercial simulator (I don't have access to them in edaplayground).

I do have access to all the simulators on EDA Playground. I created an account there years ago. I strongly recommend that you try to create your own account, if you have not already done so. It is well worth the effort. Contact their support if you have trouble creating an account or accessing all the simulators.

I tried running your code on two other simulators (Cadence and Synopsys), and they both show similar messages (errors and/or warnings). The Synopsys simulator runs, and produces reasonable results, like you see on modelsim. But, the warning message mentions that the simulator will treat it as a compile error in a future version. This is definitely code that you should fix.

Both of the other simulators produce a little more information about the nature of the problem, but they don't tell you how to fix the code. I find your code to be confusing in a number of areas. I assume the design is some variant of the AMBA AXI bus, based on the signal names. AXI is a complex design architecture, and I am surprised that you are trying to combine all of the logic of a bus master and slave into a single always block, let alone a single module.

I recommend splitting the design code up into master and slave portions. Your code uses several advanced features, such as interfaces, modports and clocking blocks. If you do not have a lot of familiarity with them yet, I suggest taking a step back and getting your code to work without them for now. Then gradually add them in one at a time.

Q: Using parent constructor derived from templated using alias vs class A:

The lookup for A finds the injected-class-name in A<int>, which refers to that specialization (though it can also be used as the template). The second A is merely matched against the first, as is necessary to allow inheriting constructors from template parameters.

However, that can’t work for B: the injected-class-name for B<int> is of course still A, since it’s the same type! B therefore refers to the alias template itself, which obviously needs template arguments. (If you supply them, you’re back to the special case that the (anonymous) constructor is selected simply by repeating the name from before the ::.)

This is related to how such declarations don’t work when the base class is dependent: name lookup doesn’t examine base class specifiers but merely (sometimes) looks inside the bases selected.

Q: typescript import error while using bun workspaces, might because how bun install node_modules in monorepo A:

I'm the author of the package bun-workspaces. I'm not sure if you meant that you are using this package in your post, but in case you are, I wouldn't think its usage should have an effect on how type imports are resolved when running scripts from workspaces. Since this question was posted, my package and Bun's monorepo features have seen some upgrades and changes as well.
